<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q93')" data-correct-answer="B">
<strong style="display: block;">In the context of Modigliani and Miller Proposition II (no taxes), which statement best describes the relationship between leverage and equity beta?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q93" value="A"> A. Increasing leverage reduces the firm's equity beta, since debt holders absorb more risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q93" value="B"> B. Increasing leverage raises the equity beta because equity holders bear a higher proportion of the firm’s total risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q93" value="C"> C. The equity beta is unaffected by leverage, as firm risk remains constant.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q93" value="D"> D. The equity beta decreases with leverage only if the cost of debt is constant.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q93" value="E"> E. The equity beta and leverage are unrelated in perfect capital markets.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q93" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. According to MM Proposition II (no taxes), leverage amplifies the risk borne by shareholders. The equity beta increases linearly with the debt-to-equity ratio, following the relation $\beta_E = \beta_U(1 + \frac{D}{E})$, because debt magnifies the volatility of equity returns.
</div>
